{{Short description|Scottish singer-songwriter and actor}} {{for|the country singer|Frankie Miller (country musician)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Frankie Miller |image = |caption = |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Francis John Miller |alias = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1949|11|2}}
[[Bridgeton, Glasgow|Bridgeton]], Glasgow, Scotland |origin = |instrument = Vocals, guitar, harmonica |genre = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[hard rock]], [[folk rock]], [[blues rock]], [[blue-eyed soul]], [[soul music|soul]] |occupation = Singer-songwriter |years_active = 1966–1994 |label = [[Chrysalis Records|Chrysalis]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[Mercury Records|Mercury]] |website = [http://www.frankiemiller.net Frankie Miller.net] |associated_acts = [[Jethro Tull (band)|Jethro Tull]], [[Phil Lynott]], [[Wild Horses (British band)|Wild Horses]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Rod Stewart]], [[The Bellamy Brothers]], [[Kim Carnes]], [[Waylon Jennings]]
[[Bob Seger]], [[Bonnie Tyler]], [[Roy Orbison]], [[Etta James]], [[Joe Walsh]], [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]], [[Thin Lizzy]], [[Clint Black]], [[Hanne Boel]], [[Robin Trower]] }} '''Francis John Miller''' (born 2 November 1949) is a Scottish rock singer-songwriter and actor.{{cite book|author=Rollingstone| title=The Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock & Roll|page=371}} Miller wrote for and performed with many recording artists and is best known for his 1977 album ''[[Full House (Frankie Miller album)|Full House]]'', the singles "Be Good To Yourself", "[[Darlin' (Poacher song)|Darlin']]" and his duet with [[Phil Lynott]] on the [[Thin Lizzy]] song "[[Still in Love with You (Thin Lizzy song)|Still in Love with You]]". ==Early life == Miller was born in [[Bridgeton, Glasgow|Bridgeton]], Glasgow, Scotland in 1949.{{cite news |url=https://www.glasgowtimes.co.uk/entertainment/14815288.frankie-miller-rocks-on-thanks-to-rod-and-elton/ |title=Frankie Miller rocks on thanks to Rod and Elton |last=Beacom |first=Brian |date=20 October 2016 |work=[[Glasgow Times]] |access-date=29 December 2022}}{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/frankie-miller-mn0000794173/biography |title=Frankie Miller Biography |first=Steve |last=Huey |publisher=allmusic.com |access-date=29 December 2022}} ==Career== ===1966–1972: Early career=== Miller began singing professionally as a teenager with a [[Glasgow]] band called The Stoics.{{cite book|author1=Hardy, Phil |author2=Laing, Dave | title=Encyclopedia of Rock |year=1988 |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofro00hard |url-access=registration |publisher= Schirmer Books|page=[https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofro00hard/page/297 297]|isbn=9780029195628 }} In mid 1970, he moved to London to further his career.{{cite book| first= Martin C.| last= Strong| year= 2000| title= The Great Rock Discography| edition= 5th| publisher= Mojo Books| location= Edinburgh| pages= 644–645| isbn= 1-84195-017-3}} ===1972–1974: First album and collaboration with Thin Lizzy=== Later in 1972, Miller signed a solo [[recording contract]] with [[Chrysalis Records]], and recorded his first LP ''Once in a Blue Moon'',{{cite web|author= Jim Worbois|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/once-in-a-blue-moon-mw0000048589|title=Once in a Blue Moon |publisher=[[AllMusic]]| access-date=25 February 2009}} with record producer Dave Robinson. The album was an early example of [[Pub rock (United Kingdom)|pub rock]], and featured backing by the pub rock band [[Brinsley Schwarz]]. Miller received consistently good reviews, although his [[single (music)|singles]] and albums were not [[record chart|chart]] [[hit record|hits]], [[Chrysalis records|Chrysalis]] continued to invest in his talent. In 1974 Miller sang "[[Still in Love with You (Thin Lizzy song)|Still in Love with You]]",{{cite web|author= Eduardo Rivadavia| url=https://www.allmusic.com/song/still-in-love-with-you-mt0030499824| title=Still in Love With You |publisher=AllMusic| access-date=25 February 2009}} as a [[duet (music)|duet]] with [[Phil Lynott]]; the song appeared on the [[Thin Lizzy]] album, ''[[Nightlife (Thin Lizzy album)|Nightlife]]''. Miller's second album ''[[High Life (Frankie Miller album)|High Life]]'', was produced and partly written by [[Allen Toussaint]] and recorded in [[Atlanta, Georgia]] during 1974.{{cite web|author= Jim Worbois|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/frankie-millers-high-life-mw0000602772| title=High Life |publisher=AllMusic| access-date=25 February 2009}} Although two album tracks, "Shoorah Shoorah" and "Play Something Sweet", subsequently provided hits for [[Betty Wright]] and [[Three Dog Night]] respectively, the album was not a commercial success. ===1975–1979: Subsequent albums and "Darlin'"=== Miller's next album ''[[The Rock (The Frankie Miller Band album)|The Rock]]'' (1975) was recorded in San Francisco using the producer Elliot Mazer, who had co-produced ''[[Harvest (Neil Young album)|Harvest]]'' for [[Neil Young]]. The next album ''[[Full House (Frankie Miller Album)|Full House]]'' (1977),{{cite web|author= Jim Warbois|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/full-house-mw0000478979| title=Full House|publisher=AllMusic| access-date=25 February 2009}} was produced by [[Chris Thomas (record producer)|Chris Thomas]]. The lead off track "Be Good to Yourself" became Miller's first UK [[top 40]] hit, peaking at No. 27 in the [[UK Singles Chart]] during June that year.{{YouTube|ZPGIQfW6lz0|Be Good to Yourself (2011 Remaster)}} In 1978 Miller hit the UK [[Top 40|top 10]] with the song "[[Darlin' (Poacher song)|Darlin']] ", which peaked at No. 6 on 14 October 1978. "[[Darlin' (Poacher song)|Darlin']] " also made the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' "Bubbling Under" chart in the US, peaking at No. 103. The next single penned by Miller "When I'm Away From You" rose to No. 42 in UK, but failed to chart in US. During 1979, Miller wrote the opening and closing songs on the film ''[[A Sense of Freedom]]'', as well as performing on them. He diversified into acting. During 1979 Miller starred in [[Peter McDougall]]'s TV film, ''[[Just a Boys' Game]]'', directed by [[John Mackenzie (film director)|John Mackenzie]]. ===1980–1993: Rock albums and "Caledonia"=== In 1980, Miller released his seventh album, ''Easy Money''. The lead single, "Why Don't You Spend the Night", was a minor hit in Australia. Miller later re-recorded the album's closing track, "Tears", as a duet with [[Bonnie Tyler]] on her album ''[[Faster Than the Speed of Night]]'' (1983). Miller moved to [[Capitol Records]] for his next album, ''Standing on the Edge''. It was noted by ''[[Newsday]]'' as a departure from the [[R&B]] influences on his earlier releases, sounding more like the music of rock bands [[Foreigner (band)|Foreigner]] and [[Bad Company]].{{cite news|last=Robins|first=Wayne|title=Some artistic exceptions to the rule|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/720896639/|work=[[Newsday]]|location=New York, New York|page=131|date=16 May 1982|accessdate=1 November 2022|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{subscription required}} In 1985, Miller released his final studio album, ''Dancing in the Rain''. It was produced by [[John Jansen (record producer)|John Jansen]], and like its predecessor, the album was noted for its rock influences. Mark Deming of [[AllMusic]] compared it to [[Robert Palmer (singer)|Robert Palmer]]'s single "[[Addicted to Love (song)|Addicted to Love]]" and said that the album sounds more "dated" than his earlier work.{{cite web|last=Deming|first=Mark|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/dancing-in-the-rain-mw0000862346|title=Frankie Miller – Dancing in the Rain|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=1 November 2022}} In 1991, Miller recorded an excerpt of "[[Caledonia (song)|Caledonia]]" for a [[Tennent Caledonian|Tennent's]] lager television advert. After a surge of requests from viewers, Miller recorded and released a full-length version as a single in 1992. It peaked at No. 45 on the UK Singles Chart.{{cite news|title=Frankie's King of the Castle!|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/809892057/|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|location=[[Glasgow|Glasgow, Scotland]]|page=9|date=4 March 1992|accessdate=1 November 2022|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{subscription required}} Later that same year, Miller recorded a second duet with Bonnie Tyler, titled "Save Your Love", for her album ''[[Angel Heart (Bonnie Tyler album)|Angel Heart]]''. In 1993, Miller recorded "Why Don't You Try Me" with [[Sarah Bettens]] for the Belgian film ''[[Ad Fundum]]''. The track was produced by [[Ry Cooder]] and peaked at No. 6 on the [[Ultratop|Belgian Flanders chart]]. "Where Do the Guilty Go?", which also featured in the film, later peaked at No. 46. ===1994–present: Illness, recovery and tribute albums=== In 1994, Miller formed a new band with [[Joe Walsh]], [[Nicky Hopkins]] and [[Ian Wallace (drummer)|Ian Wallace]]. He was writing music in New York City when he suffered a [[intracranial aneurysm|brain aneurysm]] on 25 August 1994. Miller was unconscious for five months, and when he woke up he found himself unable to speak or sing. He spent the subsequent years in physical rehabilitation. In September 1998, a benefit concert was held at the [[Queen's Hall, Edinburgh]] featuring [[Jools Holland]], [[Paul Carrack]], [[Bonnie Tyler]] and a band of musicians with disabilities. The concert was filmed as part of the [[BBC Television]] documentary series ''Ex-S'' and broadcast in 1999. The episode was titled ''Frankie Miller: Stubborn Kinda Fella'', and it documented Miller's road to recovery. The episode was nominated for Best Regional Documentary at the [[Royal Television Society]] awards.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000571/1999/1|title=Royal Television Society, UK (1999)|website=[[IMDb]]|access-date=15 July 2022}} A number of tribute albums have since been released, including ''A Tribute to Frankie Miller'' (2003), which features covers and duets with various artists,{{cite web|last=Sloan|first=Billy|url=https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/19494940.frankie-miller-tears-tennents-trainspotting-stars-tribute-scots-great/|title=Frankie Miller: Tears, Tennent's and Trainspotting stars in tribute to a Scots great|website=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]|date=8 August 2021|access-date=15 July 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210808110525/https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/19494940.frankie-miller-tears-tennents-trainspotting-stars-tribute-scots-great/|archive-date=8 August 2021|url-status=live}} and ''[[100% Pure Frankie Miller]]'' (2014) by [[Spike (musician)|Spike]] of [[The Quireboys]].{{cite web|last=Hasted|first=Nick|url=https://www.loudersound.com/reviews/spike-100-pure-frankie-miller|title=Spike: 100% Pure Frankie Miller|date=9 September 2014|access-date=15 July 2022|work=[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220715143425/https://www.loudersound.com/reviews/spike-100-pure-frankie-miller|archive-date=15 July 2022|url-status=live}} In 2006, Miller released a new studio album, ''Long Way Home'', featuring vocals extracted from demos he recorded before his brain aneurysm. The tracks were produced by [[Bill Szymczyk]], [[Will Jennings]] and [[David Naughton]].{{cite web|last=Collette|first=Doug|url=https://www.allaboutjazz.com/long-way-home-frankie-miller-jerkin-crocus-review-by-doug-collette|title=Frankie Miller: Long Way Home |date=1 June 2006|access-date=2 November 2022|work=[[All About Jazz]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221102162551/https://www.allaboutjazz.com/long-way-home-frankie-miller-jerkin-crocus-review-by-doug-collette|archive-date=2 November 2022|url-status=live}} Another album, ''[[Frankie Miller's Double Take]]'', followed in 2016, featuring 19 demos remastered into duets with other artists. The album peaked at No. 11 on the [[Scottish Singles and Albums Charts|Scottish Albums Chart]].{{cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/scottish-albums-chart/20161007/40/|title=Official Scottish Albums Chart Top 100|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|access-date=15 July 2022}} In March 2022, Miller released the track "One More Step to the Rainbow" as a protest to the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]].{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/FrankieMillerOfficial/posts/pfbid02pTBbFndMv9hVdDsgecJQNHWCECS1KgaLqWBD8T2eCChFUS1g3PRnv4pkDsDj4M2dl|title=Facebook post by Frankie Miller|publisher=[[Facebook]]|date=10 April 2022|access-date=15 July 2022}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== ====Studio albums==== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Title ! colspan="6"| Chart positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="35"| [[UK Albums Chart|{{abbr|UK|United Kingdom}}]]

'''Frankie Miller''' (born December 17, 1931, [[Victoria, Texas]]) is an American former country singer.

==Biography==
Miller landed time singing on local station [[KITE (AM)|KNAL]] and recorded for [[Gilt-Edge (record label)|Gilt Edge]] a subsidiary of [[4 Star Records]] at the beginning of the 1950s, but served from 1951-53 in the [[United States Military]] during the [[Korean War]]. In 1954 he signed with [[Columbia Records]], releasing several singles, none of which sold well. Through the latter portion of the decade, Miller performed and recorded locally, sporadically releasing singles.

He recorded his biggest hit "Blackland Farmer" for Starday in 1956. In 1959 he signed with [[Starday Records]] and released several singles which became hits on the country charts, including "Blackland Farmer", the 1956 recording, "Family Man", "Baby Rocked Her Dolly", and "A Little South of Memphis". He performed on the ''[[Louisiana Hayride]]'' and the ''[[Grand Ole Opry]]'', and was featured in ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]'' magazine.

His last charting hit came in 1964, and he recorded with [[United Artists]] in 1965, but quit the music business soon after. He worked as a car salesman in [[Arlington, Texas]] later in life. In the 1980s, [[Bear Family Records]] reissued his LPs.
